trans-unit.source: Analyze sensor data with Apache Storm and HBase | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Analyze sensor data with Apache Storm and HBase | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to connect to Apache Storm with a virtual network.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to connect to Apache Storm with a virtual network.

trans-unit.source: Use Storm with HBase to process sensor data from an event hub and visualize it with D3.js.
trans-unit.target: Use Storm with HBase to process sensor data from an event hub and visualize it with D3.js.

trans-unit.source: Analyze sensor data with Apache Storm, Event Hub, and HBase in HDInsight (Hadoop)
trans-unit.target: Analyze sensor data with Apache Storm, Event Hub, and HBase in HDInsight (Hadoop)

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Apache Storm on HDInsight to process sensor data from Azure Event Hub, and visualize it by using D3.js.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Apache Storm on HDInsight to process sensor data from Azure Event Hub, and visualize it by using D3.js.

trans-unit.source: This document also describes how to use an Azure virtual network to connect Storm on HDInsight with HBase on HDInsight, and store data from the topology into HBase.
trans-unit.target: This document also describes how to use an Azure virtual network to connect Storm on HDInsight with HBase on HDInsight, and store data from the topology into HBase.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The information in this document is based on using a Windows-based Storm on HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The information in this document is based on using a Windows-based Storm on HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: For information on working with Azure Event Hub from Linux-based Storm on HDInsight, see [Process events from Azure Event Hubs with Storm on HDInsight](hdinsight-storm-develop-java-event-hub-topology.md)
trans-unit.target: For information on working with Azure Event Hub from Linux-based Storm on HDInsight, see [Process events from Azure Event Hubs with Storm on HDInsight](hdinsight-storm-develop-java-event-hub-topology.md)

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: See [Get Azure free trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/videos/get-azure-free-trial-for-testing-hadoop-in-hdinsight/).
trans-unit.target: See [Get Azure free trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/documentation/videos/get-azure-free-trial-for-testing-hadoop-in-hdinsight/).

trans-unit.source: An [Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster](hdinsight-apache-storm-tutorial-get-started.md)
trans-unit.target: An [Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster](hdinsight-apache-storm-tutorial-get-started.md)

trans-unit.source: [Node.js](http://nodejs.org/): Used for the web dashboard and to send sensor data to Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: [Node.js](http://nodejs.org/): Used for the web dashboard and to send sensor data to Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: [Java and the JDK 1.7](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html)
trans-unit.target: [Java and the JDK 1.7](http://www.oracle.com/technetwork/java/javase/downloads/index.html)

trans-unit.source: [Maven](http://maven.apache.org/what-is-maven.html)
trans-unit.target: [Maven](http://maven.apache.org/what-is-maven.html)

trans-unit.source: [Git](http://git-scm.com/)
trans-unit.target: [Git](http://git-scm.com/)

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Java, the JDK, Maven, and Git are also available through the [Chocolatey NuGet](http://chocolatey.org/) package manager.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Java, the JDK, Maven, and Git are also available through the [Chocolatey NuGet](http://chocolatey.org/) package manager.

trans-unit.source: Architecture
trans-unit.target: Architecture

trans-unit.source: ![architecture diagram](./media/hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis/devicesarchitecture.png)
trans-unit.target: ![architecture diagram](./media/hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis/devicesarchitecture.png)

trans-unit.source: This example consists of the following components:
trans-unit.target: This example consists of the following components:

trans-unit.source: **Azure Event Hub**: Provides data that is collected from sensors.
trans-unit.target: **Azure Event Hub**: Provides data that is collected from sensors.

trans-unit.source: For this example, an application is provided that generates fake data.
trans-unit.target: For this example, an application is provided that generates fake data.

trans-unit.source: **Storm on HDInsight**: Provides real-time processing of data from Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: **Storm on HDInsight**: Provides real-time processing of data from Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: **HBase on HDInsight** (optional): Provides a persistent NoSQL data store.
trans-unit.target: **HBase on HDInsight** (optional): Provides a persistent NoSQL data store.

trans-unit.source: **Azure Virtual Network service** (optional, required if using HBase): Enables secure communications between the Storm on HDInsight and HBase on HDInsight clusters.
trans-unit.target: **Azure Virtual Network service** (optional, required if using HBase): Enables secure communications between the Storm on HDInsight and HBase on HDInsight clusters.

trans-unit.source: **Dashboard website**: An example dashboard that charts data in real time.
trans-unit.target: **Dashboard website**: An example dashboard that charts data in real time.

trans-unit.source: The website is implemented in Node.js, so it can run on any client operating system for testing, or it can be deployed to Azure Websites.
trans-unit.target: The website is implemented in Node.js, so it can run on any client operating system for testing, or it can be deployed to Azure Websites.

trans-unit.source: [Socket.io](http://socket.io/) is used for real-time communication between the Storm topology and the website.
trans-unit.target: [Socket.io](http://socket.io/) is used for real-time communication between the Storm topology and the website.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This is an implementation detail.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This is an implementation detail.

trans-unit.source: You can use any communications framework, such as raw WebSockets or SignalR.
trans-unit.target: You can use any communications framework, such as raw WebSockets or SignalR.

trans-unit.source: [D3.js](http://d3js.org/) is used to graph the data that is sent to the website.
trans-unit.target: [D3.js](http://d3js.org/) is used to graph the data that is sent to the website.

trans-unit.source: The topology reads data from Event Hub by using the **com.microsoft.eventhubs.spout.EventHubSpout** class, which is provided in the Storm on HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: The topology reads data from Event Hub by using the **com.microsoft.eventhubs.spout.EventHubSpout** class, which is provided in the Storm on HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Communication with the website is accomplished by using [socket.io-client.java](https://github.com/nkzawa/socket.io-client.java).
trans-unit.target: Communication with the website is accomplished by using [socket.io-client.java](https://github.com/nkzawa/socket.io-client.java).

trans-unit.source: Optionally, communication with HBase is accomplished by using the [org.apache.storm.hbase.bolt.HBaseBolt](https://storm.apache.org/javadoc/apidocs/org/apache/storm/hbase/bolt/class-use/HBaseBolt.html) class, which is provided as part of Storm.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, communication with HBase is accomplished by using the [org.apache.storm.hbase.bolt.HBaseBolt](https://storm.apache.org/javadoc/apidocs/org/apache/storm/hbase/bolt/class-use/HBaseBolt.html) class, which is provided as part of Storm.

trans-unit.source: The following is a diagram of the topology.
trans-unit.target: The following is a diagram of the topology.

trans-unit.source: ![topology diagram](./media/hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis/sensoranalysis.png)
trans-unit.target: ![topology diagram](./media/hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis/sensoranalysis.png)

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This is a very simplified view of the topology.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This is a very simplified view of the topology.

trans-unit.source: At run time, an instance of each component is created for each partition for the Event Hub that is being read.
trans-unit.target: At run time, an instance of each component is created for each partition for the Event Hub that is being read.

trans-unit.source: These instances are distributed across the nodes in the cluster, and data is routed between them as follows:
trans-unit.target: These instances are distributed across the nodes in the cluster, and data is routed between them as follows:

trans-unit.source: Data from the spout to the parser is load balanced.
trans-unit.target: Data from the spout to the parser is load balanced.

trans-unit.source: Data from the parser to the Dashboard and HBase (if used) is grouped by Device ID, so that messages from the same device always flow to the same component.
trans-unit.target: Data from the parser to the Dashboard and HBase (if used) is grouped by Device ID, so that messages from the same device always flow to the same component.

trans-unit.source: Components
trans-unit.target: Components

trans-unit.source: **EventHub Spout**: The spout is provided as part of the [HDInsight Storm Examples](https://github.com/hdinsight/hdinsight-storm-examples) on GitHub.
trans-unit.target: **EventHub Spout**: The spout is provided as part of the [HDInsight Storm Examples](https://github.com/hdinsight/hdinsight-storm-examples) on GitHub.

trans-unit.source: **ParserBolt.java**: The data that is emitted by the spout is raw JSON, and occasionally more than one event is emitted at a time.
trans-unit.target: **ParserBolt.java**: The data that is emitted by the spout is raw JSON, and occasionally more than one event is emitted at a time.

trans-unit.source: This bolt demonstrates how to read the data emitted by the spout, and emit it to a new stream as a tuple that contains multiple fields.
trans-unit.target: This bolt demonstrates how to read the data emitted by the spout, and emit it to a new stream as a tuple that contains multiple fields.

trans-unit.source: **DashboardBolt.java**: This demonstrates how to use the Socket.io client library for Java to send data in real time to the web dashboard.
trans-unit.target: **DashboardBolt.java**: This demonstrates how to use the Socket.io client library for Java to send data in real time to the web dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Prepare your environment
trans-unit.target: Prepare your environment

trans-unit.source: Before you use this example, you must create an Azure Event Hub, which the Storm topology reads.
trans-unit.target: Before you use this example, you must create an Azure Event Hub, which the Storm topology reads.

trans-unit.source: You must also create a Storm on HDInsight topology because the component used to read data from Event Hub is only available in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: You must also create a Storm on HDInsight topology because the component used to read data from Event Hub is only available in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Eventually the Event Hub spout will be available from Maven.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Eventually the Event Hub spout will be available from Maven.

trans-unit.source: Configure Event Hub
trans-unit.target: Configure Event Hub

trans-unit.source: Event Hub is the data source for this example.
trans-unit.target: Event Hub is the data source for this example.

trans-unit.source: Use the following steps to create a new Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: Use the following steps to create a new Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: From the [Azure Classic Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com), select **NEW | Service Bus | Event Hub | Custom Create**.
trans-unit.target: From the [Azure Classic Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com), select **NEW | Service Bus | Event Hub | Custom Create**.

trans-unit.source: In the **Add a new Event Hub** dialog box, enter an **Event Hub Name**, select the **Region** to create the hub in, and then create a new namespace or select an existing one.
trans-unit.target: In the **Add a new Event Hub** dialog box, enter an **Event Hub Name**, select the **Region** to create the hub in, and then create a new namespace or select an existing one.

trans-unit.source: Finally, click the arrow to continue.
trans-unit.target: Finally, click the arrow to continue.

trans-unit.source: In the **Configure Event Hub** dialog box, enter the **Partition count** and **Message Retention** values.
trans-unit.target: In the **Configure Event Hub** dialog box, enter the **Partition count** and **Message Retention** values.

trans-unit.source: For this example, use a partition count of 10 and a message retention of 1.
trans-unit.target: For this example, use a partition count of 10 and a message retention of 1.

trans-unit.source: When the event hub has been created, select the namespace, then select **Event Hubs**.
trans-unit.target: When the event hub has been created, select the namespace, then select **Event Hubs**.

trans-unit.source: Finally, select the event hub that you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: Finally, select the event hub that you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: Select **Configure**, then create two new access policies by using the following information.
trans-unit.target: Select **Configure**, then create two new access policies by using the following information.

trans-unit.source:
NamePermissions
DevicesSend
StormListen
trans-unit.target:
NamePermissions
DevicesSend
StormListen

trans-unit.source: After creating permissions, select the **Save** icon at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: After creating permissions, select the **Save** icon at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: This creates the shared access policies that will be used to send messages to and read messages from this hub.
trans-unit.target: This creates the shared access policies that will be used to send messages to and read messages from this hub.

trans-unit.source: After saving the policies, use the **Shared access key generator** at the bottom of the page to retrieve the key for the **devices** and **storm** policies.
trans-unit.target: After saving the policies, use the **Shared access key generator** at the bottom of the page to retrieve the key for the **devices** and **storm** policies.

trans-unit.source: Save these because you will use them later.
trans-unit.target: Save these because you will use them later.

trans-unit.source: Create the Storm on HDInsight cluster
trans-unit.target: Create the Storm on HDInsight cluster

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the [Azure Classic Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/).
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the [Azure Classic Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/).

trans-unit.source: Click **HDInsight** in the left pane, and then click **+NEW** in the lower-left corner of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click **HDInsight** in the left pane, and then click **+NEW** in the lower-left corner of the page.

trans-unit.source: Click the HDInsight icon in the second column, and then select **Custom**.
trans-unit.target: Click the HDInsight icon in the second column, and then select **Custom**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Cluster Details** page, enter the name of the new cluster, and select **Storm** for the **Cluster Type**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Cluster Details** page, enter the name of the new cluster, and select **Storm** for the **Cluster Type**.

trans-unit.source: Click the arrow to continue.
trans-unit.target: Click the arrow to continue.

trans-unit.source: Enter 1 for the number of **Data Nodes** to use for this cluster.
trans-unit.target: Enter 1 for the number of **Data Nodes** to use for this cluster.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To minimize the cost for the cluster used for this article, reduce the **Cluster Size** to 1, and delete the cluster after you have finished using it.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To minimize the cost for the cluster used for this article, reduce the **Cluster Size** to 1, and delete the cluster after you have finished using it.

trans-unit.source: Enter the administrator **User Name** and **Password**, and then click the arrow to continue.
trans-unit.target: Enter the administrator **User Name** and **Password**, and then click the arrow to continue.

trans-unit.source: For **Storage Account**, select **Create New Storage** or select an existing storage account.
trans-unit.target: For **Storage Account**, select **Create New Storage** or select an existing storage account.

trans-unit.source: Select or enter the **Account Name** and **Default container** to use.
trans-unit.target: Select or enter the **Account Name** and **Default container** to use.

trans-unit.source: Select the check mark icon in the lower-left corner to create the Storm cluster.
trans-unit.target: Select the check mark icon in the lower-left corner to create the Storm cluster.

trans-unit.source: Download and install the EventHubSpout
trans-unit.target: Download and install the EventHubSpout

trans-unit.source: Download the [HDInsight Storm Examples project](https://github.com/hdinsight/hdinsight-storm-examples/).
trans-unit.target: Download the [HDInsight Storm Examples project](https://github.com/hdinsight/hdinsight-storm-examples/).

trans-unit.source: Once downloaded, find the **lib/eventhubs/eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar** file.
trans-unit.target: Once downloaded, find the **lib/eventhubs/eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar** file.

trans-unit.source: From the command prompt, use the following command to install the **eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar** file into the local Maven store.
trans-unit.target: From the command prompt, use the following command to install the **eventhubs-storm-spout-0.9-jar-with-dependencies.jar** file into the local Maven store.

trans-unit.source: This will allow you to easily add it as a reference in the Storm project in a later step.
trans-unit.target: This will allow you to easily add it as a reference in the Storm project in a later step.

trans-unit.source: Download and configure the project
trans-unit.target: Download and configure the project

trans-unit.source: Use the following to download the project from GitHub.
trans-unit.target: Use the following to download the project from GitHub.

trans-unit.source: After the command completes, you will have the following directory structure:
trans-unit.target: After the command completes, you will have the following directory structure:

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This document does not go in to full details of the code included in this sample; however, the code is fully commented.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This document does not go in to full details of the code included in this sample; however, the code is fully commented.

trans-unit.source: Open the **Config.properties** file and add the information you previously used when creating the Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: Open the **Config.properties** file and add the information you previously used when creating the Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: Save the file after you add this information.
trans-unit.target: Save the file after you add this information.

trans-unit.source: Compile and test locally
trans-unit.target: Compile and test locally

trans-unit.source: Before testing, you must start the dashboard to view the output of the topology and generate data to store in Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: Before testing, you must start the dashboard to view the output of the topology and generate data to store in Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: Start the web application
trans-unit.target: Start the web application

trans-unit.source: Open a new command prompt or terminal, and change directories to the **hdinsight-eventhub-example/dashboard**, then use the following command to install the dependencies needed by the web application:
trans-unit.target: Open a new command prompt or terminal, and change directories to the **hdinsight-eventhub-example/dashboard**, then use the following command to install the dependencies needed by the web application:

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to start the web application:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to start the web application:

trans-unit.source: You should see a message similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should see a message similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: Open a web browser and enter **http://localhost:3000/** as the address.
trans-unit.target: Open a web browser and enter **http://localhost:3000/** as the address.

trans-unit.source: You should see a page similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should see a page similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: ![web dashboard](./media/hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis/emptydashboard.png)
trans-unit.target: ![web dashboard](./media/hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis/emptydashboard.png)

trans-unit.source: Leave this command prompt or terminal open.
trans-unit.target: Leave this command prompt or terminal open.

trans-unit.source: After testing, use Ctrl-C to stop the web server.
trans-unit.target: After testing, use Ctrl-C to stop the web server.

trans-unit.source: Start generating data
trans-unit.target: Start generating data

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] The steps in this section use Node.js so that they can be run on any platform.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] The steps in this section use Node.js so that they can be run on any platform.

trans-unit.source: For other language examples, see the **SendEvents** directory.
trans-unit.target: For other language examples, see the **SendEvents** directory.

trans-unit.source: Open a new command prompt or terminal, and change directories to **hdinsight-eventhub-example/SendEvents/nodejs**, then use the following command to install the dependencies needed by the application:
trans-unit.target: Open a new command prompt or terminal, and change directories to **hdinsight-eventhub-example/SendEvents/nodejs**, then use the following command to install the dependencies needed by the application:

trans-unit.source: Open the **app.js** file in a text editor and add the Event Hub information you obtained earlier:
trans-unit.target: Open the **app.js** file in a text editor and add the Event Hub information you obtained earlier:

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to insert new entries in Event Hub:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to insert new entries in Event Hub:

trans-unit.source: You should see several lines of output that contain the data sent to Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: You should see several lines of output that contain the data sent to Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: These will appear similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: These will appear similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: Start the topology
trans-unit.target: Start the topology

trans-unit.source: Start the topology locally by using the following command:
trans-unit.target: Start the topology locally by using the following command:

trans-unit.source: mvn compile exec:java -Dstorm.topology=com.microsoft.examples.Temperature
trans-unit.target: mvn compile exec:java -Dstorm.topology=com.microsoft.examples.Temperature

trans-unit.source: This will start the topology, read files from Event Hub, and send them to the dashboard running in Azure Websites.
trans-unit.target: This will start the topology, read files from Event Hub, and send them to the dashboard running in Azure Websites.

trans-unit.source: You should see lines appear in the web dashboard, similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: You should see lines appear in the web dashboard, similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: ![dashboard with data](./media/hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis/datadashboard.png)
trans-unit.target: ![dashboard with data](./media/hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis/datadashboard.png)

trans-unit.source: While the dashboard is running, use the `node app.js` command from the previous steps to send new data to the dashboard.
trans-unit.target: While the dashboard is running, use the `node app.js` command from the previous steps to send new data to the dashboard.

trans-unit.source: Because the temperature values are randomly generated, the graph should update to show the new values.
trans-unit.target: Because the temperature values are randomly generated, the graph should update to show the new values.

trans-unit.source: After verifying that this works, stop the topology by typing Ctrl+C.
trans-unit.target: After verifying that this works, stop the topology by typing Ctrl+C.

trans-unit.source: To stop the SendEvent app, select the window and press any key.
trans-unit.target: To stop the SendEvent app, select the window and press any key.

trans-unit.source: You can use Ctrl+C to stop the web server also.
trans-unit.target: You can use Ctrl+C to stop the web server also.

trans-unit.source: Package and deploy the topology to HDInsight
trans-unit.target: Package and deploy the topology to HDInsight

trans-unit.source: In your development environment, use the following steps to run the Temperature topology on your HDInsight Storm cluster.
trans-unit.target: In your development environment, use the following steps to run the Temperature topology on your HDInsight Storm cluster.

trans-unit.source: Publish the website dashboard
trans-unit.target: Publish the website dashboard

trans-unit.source: To deploy the dashboard to an Azure Website, follow the steps in [Build and deploy a Node.js website to Azure](../app-service-web/web-sites-nodejs-develop-deploy-mac.md).
trans-unit.target: To deploy the dashboard to an Azure Website, follow the steps in [Build and deploy a Node.js website to Azure](../app-service-web/web-sites-nodejs-develop-deploy-mac.md).

trans-unit.source: Note the URL of the website, which will be similar to **mywebsite.azurewebsites.net**.
trans-unit.target: Note the URL of the website, which will be similar to **mywebsite.azurewebsites.net**.

trans-unit.source: When the website is created, go to the site in the Azure Classic Portal and select the **Configure** tab.
trans-unit.target: When the website is created, go to the site in the Azure Classic Portal and select the **Configure** tab.

trans-unit.source: Enable **Web Sockets**, and then click **Save** at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Enable **Web Sockets**, and then click **Save** at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: Open **hdinsight-eventhub-example\TemperatureMonitor\src\main\java\com\microsoft\examples\bolts\DashboardBolt.java** and change the following line to point to the URL of the published dashboard:
trans-unit.target: Open **hdinsight-eventhub-example\TemperatureMonitor\src\main\java\com\microsoft\examples\bolts\DashboardBolt.java** and change the following line to point to the URL of the published dashboard:

trans-unit.source: Save the **DashboardBolt.java** file.
trans-unit.target: Save the **DashboardBolt.java** file.

trans-unit.source: Package and deploy the topology
trans-unit.target: Package and deploy the topology

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to create a JAR package from your project:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to create a JAR package from your project:

trans-unit.source: This will create a file named **TemperatureMonitor-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar** in the **target** directory of your project.
trans-unit.target: This will create a file named **TemperatureMonitor-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar** in the **target** directory of your project.

trans-unit.source: Follow the steps in [Deploy and manage Storm topologies](hdinsight-storm-deploy-monitor-topology.md) to upload and start the topology on your Storm on HDInsight cluster by using the **Storm Dashboard**.
trans-unit.target: Follow the steps in [Deploy and manage Storm topologies](hdinsight-storm-deploy-monitor-topology.md) to upload and start the topology on your Storm on HDInsight cluster by using the **Storm Dashboard**.

trans-unit.source: After the topology has started, open a browser to the website you published on Azure, then use the `node app.js` command to send data to Event Hub.
trans-unit.target: After the topology has started, open a browser to the website you published on Azure, then use the `node app.js` command to send data to Event Hub.

trans-unit.source: You should see the web dashboard update to display the information.
trans-unit.target: You should see the web dashboard update to display the information.

trans-unit.source: ![dashboard](./media/hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis/datadashboard.png)
trans-unit.target: ![dashboard](./media/hdinsight-storm-sensor-data-analysis/datadashboard.png)

trans-unit.source: Optional: Use HBase
trans-unit.target: Optional: Use HBase

trans-unit.source: To use Storm and HBase together, you must create an Azure virtual network and then create a Storm and HBase cluster within the network.
trans-unit.target: To use Storm and HBase together, you must create an Azure virtual network and then create a Storm and HBase cluster within the network.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure virtual network (optional)
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure virtual network (optional)

trans-unit.source: If you plan to use HBase with this example, you must create an Azure virtual network that will contain a Storm on HDInsight cluster and an HBase on HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: If you plan to use HBase with this example, you must create an Azure virtual network that will contain a Storm on HDInsight cluster and an HBase on HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the [Azure Classic Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the [Azure Classic Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com).

trans-unit.source: On the bottom of the page, click **+NEW** > **Network Services** > **Virtual Network** > **Quick Create**.
trans-unit.target: On the bottom of the page, click **+NEW** > **Network Services** > **Virtual Network** > **Quick Create**.

trans-unit.source: Type or select the following values:
trans-unit.target: Type or select the following values:

trans-unit.source: **Name**: The name of your virtual network.
trans-unit.target: **Name**: The name of your virtual network.

trans-unit.source: **Address space**: Choose an address space for the virtual network that is large enough to provide addresses for all nodes in the cluster.
trans-unit.target: **Address space**: Choose an address space for the virtual network that is large enough to provide addresses for all nodes in the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the provision will fail.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the provision will fail.

trans-unit.source: **Maximum VM count**: Choose one of the maximum virtual machine counts.
trans-unit.target: **Maximum VM count**: Choose one of the maximum virtual machine counts.

trans-unit.source: **Location**: The location must be the same as the HBase cluster that you will create.
trans-unit.target: **Location**: The location must be the same as the HBase cluster that you will create.

trans-unit.source: **DNS server**: This article uses the internal DNS server provided by Azure; therefore, you can choose **None**.
trans-unit.target: **DNS server**: This article uses the internal DNS server provided by Azure; therefore, you can choose **None**.

trans-unit.source: More advanced networking configurations with custom DNS servers are also supported.
trans-unit.target: More advanced networking configurations with custom DNS servers are also supported.

trans-unit.source: For the detailed guidance, see [Name Resolution (DNS)](../virtual-network/virtual-networks-name-resolution-for-vms-and-role-instances.md).
trans-unit.target: For the detailed guidance, see [Name Resolution (DNS)](../virtual-network/virtual-networks-name-resolution-for-vms-and-role-instances.md).

trans-unit.source: Click **Create a Virtual Network**.
trans-unit.target: Click **Create a Virtual Network**.

trans-unit.source: The new virtual network name will appear in the list.
trans-unit.target: The new virtual network name will appear in the list.

trans-unit.source: Wait until the Status column shows **Created**.
trans-unit.target: Wait until the Status column shows **Created**.

trans-unit.source: In the main pane, click the virtual network you just created.
trans-unit.target: In the main pane, click the virtual network you just created.

trans-unit.source: On the top of the page, click **DASHBOARD**.
trans-unit.target: On the top of the page, click **DASHBOARD**.

trans-unit.source: Under **quick glance**, make a note of **VIRTUAL NETWORK ID**.
trans-unit.target: Under **quick glance**, make a note of **VIRTUAL NETWORK ID**.

trans-unit.source: You will need it when provisioning the Storm and HBase clusters.
trans-unit.target: You will need it when provisioning the Storm and HBase clusters.

trans-unit.source: At the top of the page, click **CONFIGURE**.
trans-unit.target: At the top of the page, click **CONFIGURE**.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the page, the default subnet name is **Subnet-1**.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the page, the default subnet name is **Subnet-1**.

trans-unit.source: Use the **add subnet** button to add **Subnet-2**.
trans-unit.target: Use the **add subnet** button to add **Subnet-2**.

trans-unit.source: These subnets will house the Storm and HBase clusters.
trans-unit.target: These subnets will house the Storm and HBase clusters.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] In this article, we will be using clusters with only one node.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] In this article, we will be using clusters with only one node.

trans-unit.source: If you are creating multinode clusters, you must verify the **CIDR(ADDRESS COUNT)** for the subnet that will be used for the cluster.
trans-unit.target: If you are creating multinode clusters, you must verify the **CIDR(ADDRESS COUNT)** for the subnet that will be used for the cluster.

trans-unit.source: The address count must be greater than the number of worker nodes plus seven (Gateway: 2, Headnode: 2, Zookeeper: 3).
trans-unit.target: The address count must be greater than the number of worker nodes plus seven (Gateway: 2, Headnode: 2, Zookeeper: 3).

trans-unit.source: For example, if you need a 10 node HBase cluster, the address count for the subnet must be greater than 17 (10+7).
trans-unit.target: For example, if you need a 10 node HBase cluster, the address count for the subnet must be greater than 17 (10+7).

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the deployment will fail.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the deployment will fail.

trans-unit.source: It is highly recommended to designate a single subnet for one cluster.
trans-unit.target: It is highly recommended to designate a single subnet for one cluster.

trans-unit.source: Click **Save** at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click **Save** at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: Create a Storm and HBase cluster on the virtual network
trans-unit.target: Create a Storm and HBase cluster on the virtual network

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the [Azure Classic Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/).
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the [Azure Classic Portal](https://manage.windowsazure.com/).

trans-unit.source: Click **HDInsight** in the left pane, and then click **+NEW** in the lower-left corner of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click **HDInsight** in the left pane, and then click **+NEW** in the lower-left corner of the page.

trans-unit.source: Click the HDInsight icon in the second column, and then select **Custom**.
trans-unit.target: Click the HDInsight icon in the second column, and then select **Custom**.

trans-unit.source: On the **Cluster Details** page, enter the name of the new cluster, and select **Storm** for the **Cluster Type**.
trans-unit.target: On the **Cluster Details** page, enter the name of the new cluster, and select **Storm** for the **Cluster Type**.

trans-unit.source: Click the arrow to continue.
trans-unit.target: Click the arrow to continue.

trans-unit.source: Enter 1 for the number of **Data Nodes** to use for this cluster.
trans-unit.target: Enter 1 for the number of **Data Nodes** to use for this cluster.

trans-unit.source: For **Region/Virtual Network**, select the Azure virtual network that you created earlier.
trans-unit.target: For **Region/Virtual Network**, select the Azure virtual network that you created earlier.

trans-unit.source: For **Virtual Network Subnets**, select **Subnet-1**.
trans-unit.target: For **Virtual Network Subnets**, select **Subnet-1**.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] To minimize the cost for the cluster used for this article, reduce the **Cluster Size** to 1, and delete the cluster after you have finished using it.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] To minimize the cost for the cluster used for this article, reduce the **Cluster Size** to 1, and delete the cluster after you have finished using it.

trans-unit.source: Enter the administrator **User Name** and **Password**, then click the arrow to continue.
trans-unit.target: Enter the administrator **User Name** and **Password**, then click the arrow to continue.

trans-unit.source: For **Storage Account**, select **Create New Storage** or select an existing storage account.
trans-unit.target: For **Storage Account**, select **Create New Storage** or select an existing storage account.

trans-unit.source: Select or enter the **Account Name** and **Default container** to use.
trans-unit.target: Select or enter the **Account Name** and **Default container** to use.

trans-unit.source: Select the check mark icon in the lower-left corner to create the Storm cluster.
trans-unit.target: Select the check mark icon in the lower-left corner to create the Storm cluster.

trans-unit.source: Repeat these steps to create a new **HBase** cluster.
trans-unit.target: Repeat these steps to create a new **HBase** cluster.

trans-unit.source: The following are the key differences:
trans-unit.target: The following are the key differences:

trans-unit.source: **Cluster Type**: Select **HBase**
trans-unit.target: **Cluster Type**: Select **HBase**

trans-unit.source: **Virtual Network Subnets**: Select **Subnet-2**
trans-unit.target: **Virtual Network Subnets**: Select **Subnet-2**

trans-unit.source: **Storage Account**: You should use a different container than the one used for the Storm cluster.
trans-unit.target: **Storage Account**: You should use a different container than the one used for the Storm cluster.

trans-unit.source: Discover the HBase DNS suffix
trans-unit.target: Discover the HBase DNS suffix

trans-unit.source: To write to HBase from the Storm cluster, you must use the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) for the HBase cluster.
trans-unit.target: To write to HBase from the Storm cluster, you must use the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) for the HBase cluster.

trans-unit.source: Use the following command to discover this information:
trans-unit.target: Use the following command to discover this information:

trans-unit.source: In the JSON data returned, find the **"host_name"** entry.
trans-unit.target: In the JSON data returned, find the **"host_name"** entry.

trans-unit.source: This will contain the FQDN for the nodes in the cluster, for example:
trans-unit.target: This will contain the FQDN for the nodes in the cluster, for example:

trans-unit.source: The portion of the domain name beginning with the cluster name is the DNS suffix, for example, **mycluster.b1.cloudapp.net**.
trans-unit.target: The portion of the domain name beginning with the cluster name is the DNS suffix, for example, **mycluster.b1.cloudapp.net**.

trans-unit.source: Enable the HBase bolt
trans-unit.target: Enable the HBase bolt

trans-unit.source: Open **hdinsight-eventhub-example\TemperatureMonitor\conf\hbase-site.xml** and replace the `suffix` entries in the following line with the DNS suffix obtained previously for the HBase cluster.
trans-unit.target: Open **hdinsight-eventhub-example\TemperatureMonitor\conf\hbase-site.xml** and replace the `suffix` entries in the following line with the DNS suffix obtained previously for the HBase cluster.

trans-unit.source: Save the file after you make these changes.
trans-unit.target: Save the file after you make these changes.

trans-unit.source: This will be used by the HBase bolt to communicate with the HBase cluster.
trans-unit.target: This will be used by the HBase bolt to communicate with the HBase cluster.

trans-unit.source: Open **hdinsight-eventhub-example\TemperatureMonitor\src\main\java\com\microsoft\examples\bolts\** in a text editor, and uncomment the following lines by removing the `//` from the beginning.
trans-unit.target: Open **hdinsight-eventhub-example\TemperatureMonitor\src\main\java\com\microsoft\examples\bolts\** in a text editor, and uncomment the following lines by removing the `//` from the beginning.

trans-unit.source: Save the file after you make this change.
trans-unit.target: Save the file after you make this change.

trans-unit.source: This enables the HBase bolt.
trans-unit.target: This enables the HBase bolt.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] You should only enable the HBase bolt when you are deploying to the Storm cluster, not when you are testing locally.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] You should only enable the HBase bolt when you are deploying to the Storm cluster, not when you are testing locally.

trans-unit.source: HBase and Storm data
trans-unit.target: HBase and Storm data

trans-unit.source: Before running the topology, you must prepare HBase to accept the data.
trans-unit.target: Before running the topology, you must prepare HBase to accept the data.

trans-unit.source: Use Remote Desktop to connect to the HBase cluster.
trans-unit.target: Use Remote Desktop to connect to the HBase cluster.

trans-unit.source: From the desktop, start the HDInsight command-line and enter the following commands:
trans-unit.target: From the desktop, start the HDInsight command-line and enter the following commands:

trans-unit.source: cd %HBASE_HOME% bin\hbase shell
trans-unit.target: cd %HBASE_HOME% bin\hbase shell

trans-unit.source: From the HBase shell, enter the following command to create a table to store the sensor data:
trans-unit.target: From the HBase shell, enter the following command to create a table to store the sensor data:

trans-unit.source: create 'SensorData', 'cf'
trans-unit.target: create 'SensorData', 'cf'

trans-unit.source: Verify that the table contains no data by entering the following command:
trans-unit.target: Verify that the table contains no data by entering the following command:

trans-unit.source: scan 'SensorData'
trans-unit.target: scan 'SensorData'

trans-unit.source: When you have started the topology on the Storm cluster and processed data, you can use the `scan 'SensorData'` command again to verify that data was inserted into HBase.
trans-unit.target: When you have started the topology on the Storm cluster and processed data, you can use the `scan 'SensorData'` command again to verify that data was inserted into HBase.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: You have now learned how to use Storm to read data from Event Hub and display information from Storm on an external dashboard by using SignalR and D3.js.
trans-unit.target: You have now learned how to use Storm to read data from Event Hub and display information from Storm on an external dashboard by using SignalR and D3.js.

trans-unit.source: If you used the optional steps, you also learned how to configure HDInsight in a virtual network and how to communicate between a Storm topology and HBase by using the HBase bolt.
trans-unit.target: If you used the optional steps, you also learned how to configure HDInsight in a virtual network and how to communicate between a Storm topology and HBase by using the HBase bolt.

trans-unit.source: For more examples of Storm topologies with HDinsight, see:
trans-unit.target: For more examples of Storm topologies with HDinsight, see:

trans-unit.source: [Example topologies for Storm on HDInsight](hdinsight-storm-example-topology.md)
trans-unit.target: [Example topologies for Storm on HDInsight](hdinsight-storm-example-topology.md)

trans-unit.source: For more information about Apache Storm, see the [Apache Storm](https://storm.incubator.apache.org/) site.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Apache Storm, see the [Apache Storm](https://storm.incubator.apache.org/) site.

trans-unit.source: For more information about HBase on HDInsight, see the [HBase with HDInsight Overview](hdinsight-hbase-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information about HBase on HDInsight, see the [HBase with HDInsight Overview](hdinsight-hbase-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: For more information about Socket.io, see the [socket.io](http://socket.io/) site.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Socket.io, see the [socket.io](http://socket.io/) site.

trans-unit.source: For more information about D3.js, see [D3.js - Data Driven Documents](http://d3js.org/).
trans-unit.target: For more information about D3.js, see [D3.js - Data Driven Documents](http://d3js.org/).

trans-unit.source: For information about creating topologies in Java, see [Develop Java topologies for Apache Storm on HDInsight](hdinsight-storm-develop-java-topology.md).
trans-unit.target: For information about creating topologies in Java, see [Develop Java topologies for Apache Storm on HDInsight](hdinsight-storm-develop-java-topology.md).

trans-unit.source: For information about creating topologies in .NET, see [Develop C# topologies for Apache Storm on HDInsight using Visual Studio](hdinsight-storm-develop-csharp-visual-studio-topology.md).
trans-unit.target: For information about creating topologies in .NET, see [Develop C# topologies for Apache Storm on HDInsight using Visual Studio](hdinsight-storm-develop-csharp-visual-studio-topology.md).
